msDesc.head: Thomas Hoccleve and John Lydgate: Poetry on governance and death

msItem.author: Thomas Hoccleve
msItem.title: De regimine principum
msItem.incipit:
Knyȝthood a wake þou slepist to longe
Thi brother see nowe ny deed for mischeef
msItem.explicit:
To þee þat al saist of loues feruence
That knowith he whom no þing is hid fro
msItem.note: Lines 1-896 wanting due to loss of quires at the beginning.

msItem.incipit:
Aftir þat heruest Inned had hise sheues
And that the groun sesoun of Mihelmesse
msItem.explicit: I braste once⸝ on þe morede⸝ and þus began.
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith my prolog⹎ and folwith my compleinte.

msItem.incipit: Almyȝty god⸝ as liketh his goodnesse
msItem.explicit:
And thi ȝistis and benefices alle
And vn to thi mercy and grace I calle

msItem.author: Thomas Hoccleve
msItem.title: Dialogus cum amico
msItem.incipit:
And endid my compleinte in this manere
Don knockid at my chaumbre dore sore
msItem.explicit:
Wole I translate and that my gifte I hope
Shal pourge as clene as keuerchiefs dooþ sope
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit dialogus & incipit quedam fabula quadam bona & nobili Imperatrice Romana

msItem.author: Thomas Hoccleve
msItem.title: Tale of the Emperor Gerelaus
msItem.incipit:
In romain actis writen is thus
Somtime an emperour in the citee
msItem.explicit:
And to in this wise and manere it seith
Wiche to that tale is good be knytte in feith
msItem.finalRubric: here endith þe Prolog and begynneþ þe moralizing of þe (remainder under the binding)
msItem.note: Ends imperfectly due to loss of folios.

msItem.author: Thomas Hoccleve
msItem.title: Ars sciendi mori
msItem.incipit:
Nowe herkene a doctrine substancial
ffirste howe lerne to die telle wole I
msItem.explicit: That it may haue þe lyf þat hath noon ende
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith to lerne to die⸝ And bigynneth a prolog on þe ixᵉ leson þat is redde on alle halwen day

msItem.incipit: To oþer þre partes⸝ edich in þe book
msItem.explicit:
That for to comprehende þat gladnesse
Verrely no wit may ne tounge expresse

msItem.incipit: Lo þus is seid of þat citee in a place
msItem.note: Prose translation of the ninth lesson at matins for All Saints’ Day.

msItem.rubric: Here bigynneþ þe prologe of the tale of Ionatas
msItem.incipit:
This book to han endid had I thouȝt
But my frende made me chaunge my cast
msItem.explicit:
The copie on þe morede sente he me
And þus I wroot as ȝe may here see
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the Prolog and bygynneth the tale

msItem.incipit:
SOmtyme an Emperour⸝ prudent and wys
Regned in Rome⸝ and hadde sones thre
msItem.explicit:
His lyf he ledde⸝ yn to his dyng day
And so god us graunte⸝ þat we do may.
msItem.finalRubric: Here endiþ þe tale of Ionatas⹎ & of a wickid womman and bigynneth þe moralising ther of.

msItem.incipit: This Emperour above expressid. is oure lorde god þat hath .iii. sones
msItem.explicit: þe kyngdom of hevene To wiche god bringe vs alle. Amen. Amen. Amen.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: The Dance of Macabre
msItem.incipit:
O ȝee folkes harde hertid as a stone
Wich to þe worlde haue al ȝour aduertence
msItem.explicit:
Of her tunge I haue no suffisaunce
Her corious metris in englisshe to translate
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the daunce of deeth

msItem.note: Items added in a later hand, third quarter of the 15th century.

msItem.title: A Dialogue between Death and the Lady
msItem.incipit:
Let se your hand my ladi dam emperys
Haue no disdeine with me for to dame
msItem.explicit:
Raunson keurede frendschip nor vordines
Deth is on my hy estate to assayle

msItem.title: Erthe upon Erthe
msItem.incipit:
Erthe apon erthe wonderly wroth
Erthe apon erthe hath worschyp of noþch
msItem.explicit:
Now pray we god þat al erth wrowth
þat erth owt of erth to blys myth be browth

supportDesc.extent: ii (modern paper flyleaves) + 158 + 1 (medieval flyleaf) + ii (paper flyleaves, foliated 160 and 161) leaves 253 188
supportDesc.collation: Bound mainly in gatherings of 8. Signatures in the lower margin on line for catchwords, upper case letters plus Roman numerals, in red ink: first half of quire, beginning C.i. on fol. 1 and continuing through 'Z' for last quire. Catchwords in black ink, by scribe, in line ruled for them.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in long lines, c. 33 per page. Ruled with five vertical guidelines: two enclosing Latin glosses in the outer margin and three for the text column, with a narrow double at left side of the text column to enclose an initial letter of first line of each stanza. Fourteen horizontal guidelines: two for a running title (not executed), two for the first line of each of four stanzas; a double below last stanza, and a double in lower margin for catchwords, all running to edge of page. Ruling within text column. Written area 175 85–90

handDesc.handNote: Fols. 1r–158r written by the ‘Selden scribe’ in Anglicana formata, also found in Cambridge, Queen's College, MS. 12. See Linne R. Mooney, ‘A Scribe of Lydgate’s Troy Book and London Book Production in the First Half of the Fifteenth Century’, in Pursuing Middle English Manuscripts and Their Texts: Essays in Honour of Ralph Hanna, ed. by Simon Horobin and Aditi Nafde (Turnhout: Brepols, 2017), pp. 19–42.

decoDesc.decoNote: Marginal headings in red, written by the scribe.
Fine miniature depicting a man on his deathbed with attending priest and approaching skeleton (fol. 118r).

Texts begin with 4-line pink and blue parti-coloured initials highlighted in white on solid gold ground, with a foliage pattern in the centre of the letter; at the edges, gold ground leading to sprays with green leaves and blue, red, and gold balls.
Smaller two-line blue lombard initials, red pen-work flourishing; one-line blue initials with red pen-work flourishing.
Blue paraphs with red penwork decoration in prose sections
Marginal scribbles, fol. 91v. (Pächt and Alexander iii. 888, pl. LXXXIV)

binding.p: Brown tanned calf over laminated pulpboard.

history.provenance: Richard Burnett (inscription, 16th century): evidently responsible for marginal annotion after fol. 83r.

recordHist.source: Description by Andrew Dunning (February 2022), based in part on the Digital Index of Middle English Verse and Late Medieval English Scribes. Summary Catalogue, Vol. 2 Part 1, p. 635 Summary Catalogue, Vol. 2 Part 1, p. 636

ref.title: Digital Index of Middle English Verse

revisionDesc.change: Andrew Dunning Revised with consultation of original.
